customer_name: Out of Africa Wildlife Park, LLC
customer_addr:
4020 N. Cherry Rd
Camp Verde, AZ 86322
site_name: Out of Africa Wildlife Park, LLC

citations.narrative:
The facility is not ensuring there is sufficient distance and/or barriers between two giraffes and the general viewing public.
Two giraffes are fed their diet and mineral block in containers directly on top of the enclosure fence by the public walkway.
The enclosure fence measures 5 feet 8 inches high at the lowest point. The public barrier that is approximately 3 feet tall
is located 5 feet 2 inches away from the enclosure fence. When the animals are at their feeding station, the inspector
standing at the public barrier would be able to make contact with the giraffes if they lowered their heads over the
enclosure fence. A giraffe did have its neck erect over the enclosure fence. A facility representative stated it is not
intended for the public to touch or feed the animals at this location. There are no dedicated employees at the giraffe
feeding station to monitor activity. Animals and the public are at risk of harm during handling activities of animals, such as
feeding, where animals may make contact with the public without facility supervision due to inadequate barriers.
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by 19 September 2025.

The fence for the Safari enclosure is in disrepair along the main public walkway. The wire grid fence is sagging and
bowed out in between wooden posts. Some of the posts are leaning towards the public walkway at an approximately 15-
degree angle. These defects appear to be due to soil erosion and animal activity. The lowest fence height measured was
5 feet 8 inches tall. This enclosure houses giraffe, zebra, watusi, Asiatic water buffalo, roan antelope, nilgai and
waterbuck. A facility representative states there are materials available and plans to upgrade and move the enclosure
fence line further away from the public barrier. At time of inspection, work had not yet begun on this project. Failure to
maintain housing facilities in good repair can affect the structural integrity of the enclosures which may lead to the injury or
escape of the animals such as large exotic hoof stock and megaherbivores contained in them.
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The
outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from
injury and to contain the animals.
Correct by 31 October 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1) 
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility is not ensuring there is sufficient distance and/or barriers between two giraffes and the general viewing public. 
Two giraffes are fed their diet and mineral block in containers directly on top of the enclosure fence by the public walkway. 
The enclosure fence measures 5 feet 8 inches high at the lowest point. The public barrier that is approximately 3 feet tall 
is located 5 feet 2 inches away from the enclosure fence. When the animals are at their feeding station, the inspector 
standing at the public barrier would be able to make contact with the giraffes if they lowered their heads over the 
enclosure fence. A giraffe did have its neck erect over the enclosure fence. A facility representative stated it is not 
intended for the public to touch or feed the animals at this location. There are no dedicated employees at the giraffe 
feeding station to monitor activity. Animals and the public are at risk of harm during handling activities of animals, such as 
feeding, where animals may make contact with the public without facility supervision due to inadequate barriers. 
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public. 
 
Correct by 19 September 2025. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The fence for the Safari enclosure is in disrepair along the main public walkway. The wire grid fence is sagging and 
bowed out in between wooden posts. Some of the posts are leaning towards the public walkway at an approximately 15-
degree angle. These defects appear to be due to soil erosion and animal activity. The lowest fence height measured was 
5 feet 8 inches tall. This enclosure houses giraffe, zebra, watusi, Asiatic water buffalo, roan antelope, nilgai and 
waterbuck. A facility representative states there are materials available and plans to upgrade and move the enclosure 
fence line further away from the public barrier. At time of inspection, work had not yet begun on this project. Failure to 
maintain housing facilities in good repair can affect the structural integrity of the enclosures which may lead to the injury or 
escape of the animals such as large exotic hoof stock and megaherbivores contained in them. 
 
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The

outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from 
injury and to contain the animals. 
 
Correct by 31 October 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representatives.
